Reviews.Title: What else do you wan for the price?
Reviews.Author: skaughtz
Reviews.Content: I recently purchased this television on sale for $300 to serve as an extra TV for my man cave bar.  Here's a quick rundown of some important points:- These TCL televisions are cheap, but don't seem to be of poor quality.  The television itself is sleek and thin and other than the location of the control buttons on the TV itself (they are arranged behind the front bezel on the right side), everything else is laid out well.  This TV comes with a two year warranty and unless I'm mistaken, they use Samsung screens.- Out of the box, the picture is clear and crisp.  Colors are bright and blacks are dark.  I noticed a little bit of a red tinge to the skin of some people, but with a little tweaking that went away easily.  In fact, it was so mundane and the factory settings were so good that I had to force myself to change it.  The brightness of the TV seems to have quite a range, but it wasn't difficult to find the right lighting for the room I have it in.- I was worried when I purchased this that it only had a 60Hz refresh rate, but the other positive aspects outweighed this one concern (40", 1080p, LED, $300, etc...).  I have watched nearly every sport that ESPN airs on this television, and the only blur that I could notice was immediately after someone struck a tennis ball or punted a soccer ball across the field.  Even then, I could only notice it if I was looking for it and really paying attention.  I watched the O's game on it last night and I couldn't notice any blur whatsoever.  They lost, but looked great doing it.- The sound is absolutely fine for a TV this size.  I've read quite a few television reviews, and someone always seems to complain about the sound, no matter what make or model.  If you desire 7.1 surround quality from this (or any) television, buy the appropriate audio equipment.  Otherwise, in my opinion, the sound that this thing produces is perfectly fine.If you want a large screen for a cheap price, stop here.  This TV might not have all of the bells and whistles that Samsung or Sony offer, but you also are not paying anywhere near those prices, either.  This TV offers a great picture at a great price (at 40"), and for my money that is all that I really care about.

Reviews.Title: Review for the 50" model
Reviews.Author: Ali
Reviews.Content: Tv arrived in great shape. Packaging was adequate and the delivery box was in great condition. I immediately started setting it up. First thing I did was install the stand. The bracket that you use to install the stand seemed like it was the wrong size at first, but then I realized the holes for the screw that go into the stand need to be aligned just right for the bracket to fit properly so all four screws can be screwed in. A little annoying but no big deal.Another thing I noticed was that the glass base has these "smudges" if you look at it directly from the top and shine a light on it. You cannot clean these because they are on the inside between the glass base and the bottom that they glued to the base. Disappointing at first but once the TV is set up and you are looking at it from the front, these smudges are invisible. You cannot see them at all. They are only visible if you stand right on top and look down and shine a light. So unless you have guests that are going to bring flash lights with them, walk up to your tv, somehow angle themselves in the perfect position and then shine the flash light at the perfect angle, this will not be an issue.Once the glass base was set up, I turned it on not knowing what to expect. I have read around the internet and found that these TV's have Samsung panels. If you read the spec sheet, it states it has "Clear Motion Index 120Hz". All TV manufacturers have their own terminology on what they call their technology that counters motion blur on LCD panels. LG uses "Trumotion" while Sony uses "Motionflow". Samsung uses "Clear Motion Rate" which is similar to what the specs on this TV state. I did some further digging and found that around 2008, Samsung signed a contract with TCL to manufacture panels for their TV's. So in reality, its not TCL that uses Samsung panels, but the other way around.Once I booted up the TV, it asked me a couple of questions such as choice of language and time zone and then it started searching for channels. This process was slower than I expected but not super slow. Took about 5 minutes to find all the channels. The picture looked decent but it was time to dig into the menu.It came with the latest firmware installed so thats a big plus. Some previous reviews state the previous firmware had some issues with "TINT". No need to update the TV since it already came pre-installed with the latest version (From May 2013). One thing I found thats buggy is that I picked the correct timezone for California but if I chose to auto set the time, the clock was 1 hour behind the actual time. No biggie. I will primarily use this as a computer monitor so it does not affect me. However, if you use it as a TV, your channel guide might show the wrong times. Simple fix is so set the time manually if the auto update shows the wrong time.Now I will discuss my experience with using it with a computer. If you want to know about the picture quality and colors etc, you can skip this paragraph and move onto the next. I hooked up my computer to the HDMI port and powered everything on. Even though the website claims its 120HZ, this might refer to TV channels only (or I may have missed a setting). My computer detected the max refresh rate at being 60HZ @ 1080P. The screen was not taking full advantage of the panel as well so I had to use my graphic cards control center to stretch the screen so it touches all four corners of the display. I only had to stretch it an inch in all directions. This could be due to my graphics card however and might not be an issue with your computer. If it is an issue, its pretty slight and easy to fix. I have had the computer hooked up to a 120" 3D projector that does 720P all this time. I launched a couple of games to see them in 1080P for the first time and they look fantastic. I did not sense any screen lag. Specs around the internet state it has a 8MS response time and I believe this.Now about the colors and picture quality etc. First, a bit of a background for my color preferences. I own a 30 Inch Apple Cinema Display which hooks up with a DVI cable (Digital Video Interface) to my computer. Out of all the projectors/tv screens i've had, the Cinema Display in my opinion has had the best most accurate colors I have ever seen on a display. I also own an iPad with retina display which also has pretty good colors. Initially when I got the iPad, I would sometimes bring up similar pictures on the Cinema Display and the iPad and compare the two to see the difference in color. The iPad looked really good when put next to regular TV's and other displays but in front of the Cinema Display, it was slightly below the quality the Cinema Display was able to output. However, the Cinema Display I have runs for about $2500 and the iPad is around 499 so this is expected. Long story short. The iPad puts out really good colors and can beat most expensive TV's in color accuracy (In my opinion). And in the next paragraph I will explain this rant.Initially when I turned the TV on, the colors looked ok and the picture looked ok. I was not expecting much for $500 but I still had hope I found a "deal". I was right. I put the iPad next to the TV and played around with the settings to match the colors on screen as close as I could to the iPad and voila. Now I have a pretty good picture and it looks fantastic. The black levels on this thing are amazing and the colors are really good as well. You will not be disappointed once you set the picture. I am sure $2000+ tv's have better picture than this TV but this TV is no slouch in the picture department. I did indeed find a deal and I am very happy with this purchase. Below are the settings I use. Someone else posted settings and I tried those first but the TV became too dark and weird. I guess to each their own. These settings helped me match colors with my iPad:Brightness: 53Contrast: 35Saturation: 40Sharpness: 15Tint: 53Color Mode: NormalBack light: 80Dynamic Backlight: OFF (I kept this ON for a bit but you can see the backlight dimming on and off rapidly. Its not implemented well. This was during a game on my PC. It might work better with a movie which I have not tried yet.)Dynamic Light sensor: OFFObviously, everyone has a preference for color etc. You should play around with yours till you see what you like. Its totally doable and the screen will come close to what you find appealing.The speakers on the TV are decent. Virtual Surround sound does pretty much what every other virtual surround system does. The bass is lacking but overall the speakers are really good for TV viewing. You obviously cannot compare them to a dedicated home theater sound system. However, they do not sound cheap. No crackle or pops or anything like that.As for the cosmetics of the TV. The bezel is thin and the back of the TV (when viewed from the side) is actually thinner than I expected. The pictures of the TV do not do it justice. Its thinner than you would expect at this price point.All the HDMI ports are on the left side of the TV and so is the antennae/coaxial connecter. The power buttons etc are on the right side. The remote control is pretty simple and well laid out.Everything about this TV is good. If you have been staring at it for a while, just buy it. You will not be disappointed. In the future if you do spring for newer technology or a higher end TV, this could go into a spare room. You cant beat it at this price.If you have any questions, post them in the comments and I will try to reply.

Reviews.Title: Finally, The TV I've Been Looking For!
Reviews.Author: Bruce
Reviews.Content: Let me start by saying I have not had this TV long (2 days), but it does not disappoint. When shopping for a TV you need to determine what it is you want before you begin looking, then set a budget for what you want to spend.  If you can get everything you want for the money you budget, you will be happy.  For me, I wanted between 46" and 55", 1080p, LED, 120hz, NO 3D, NO smart TV, Energy Star, thin bevel and thin TV.  I can't believe this TV is only $500. I was shopping every day for nearly a month, spending hours researching TVs until I discovered this one.  It seems like every large flat screen TV is either Smart/3d or both. Those options not only fatten the price tag, but also the TV itself. Anyways, for all the options I wanted it looked like I was going to have to spend between $700 and $900 to get it all.  I ordered two other TVs only to immediately cancel my order because I did not get that satisfied feeling when I hit COMPLETE ORDER. I was trying to rush buying a TV, but that is a gingerly process that requires patience. When I saw this TV I knew it was what I had been waiting for.  I don't make a lot of money. It takes me around 43 hours to make $500, so I value a dollar greatly. I'm cheap and I can say with extreme confidence that this TV is a hidden gem.  Don't be fooled by the unfamiliar brand. Look at the features and you can tell it's quality.  $10 energy rating on a 50" is one of the lowest I've seen and that can be a big clue as to the quality of a TV. It lets you know how efficient it is. If you look at some of the cheapest TVs they have ratings getting close to $30. That's a hint for cheap components and design. Comes with a 2 year limited warranty.Negatives:I found two screws on the floor during setup and at first thought they were left over from putting the entertainment stand together. Then I realized they fell out of the TV.  Screws were loosened from either travel or never properly screwed to begin with. No damage done, but has me slightly questioning craftmanship now.  It made it to me in one piece so I'm just being paranoid.I also can't hook up my soundbar directly to the TV with a digital audio optical cable. I'm pretty sure I can hook my soundbar up through my bluray player, but haven't had time to investigate.The stand isn't swivel. If you plan to use the stand and not mount it, it's fixed in place. Not a big deal for me.All the HDMI ports are on the same side.Pros: I haven't noticed any glare yet, but that's because I'm never home during the day.  If you are trying to watch TV with the sun shining through the windows, you probably watch too much TV. I don't know if this screen is MATTE, or whatever it's called.CHEAP, 1080P, 120 HZ, THIN BEVEL, THIN TV, ENERGY EFFICIENT, 3 HDMI PORTS.  I CAN'T WAIT TO WATCH BREAKING BAD ON THIS TONIGHT!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! AAAHHHHHHHHHHHH!!!!If you need to spend all your money to feel good about yourself or make your kids love you, buy a different TV. If you make less than $20,000 a year and have poor credit, buy a $2,000 projector. If you make less than $30,000 but don't want to feel like it, buy this TV! If you make more than $50,000 but appreciate money, buy this TV!  I'll give a more accurate review upon further use.

Reviews.Content: I purchased this television after a week of shopping around. I looked at the specs on several TV's and decided on this one. Reviews.Title: Buy this TV
Reviews.Author: dabutcher
Reviews.Content: I had purchased the 48 " TCL  240 Hz TV a couple of months ago and I was real impressed with the picture.  The 40" was an easy purchase to replace a 32"  I have had for a few years now. I have it hooked directly to raw cable (no converter) and the picture is amazing . The tuner picks up on the broadcast HD signals  so I get PBS and local broadcast HD  without an external converter. I have one HDMI  port populated with a computer and they sync seamlessly. HBO GO  Cinemax and Amazon Prime programming pass through in HD  flawlessly, even with a wireless connection . The Tuner also displays non HD programs in better than expected resolution. Above the volume up on the remote control is a button the says PIC . If you encounter a dark picture scroll though the presets you will find one that says personal. I love to watch Law and Order but there are a lot of dark scenes (the interrogation room ) You can set up the personal button to bring up the brightness and contrast and bump up the colors, this preset will be saved. The other presets are Vibrant Cinematic  Sports  Natural and Eco.

Reviews.Title: Very disappointed for TCL Customer Service
Reviews.Author: Cam C
Reviews.Content: I ordered this tv after my 50 inch Samsung Plasma cracked in an accident.  I was not ready to drop 1k on a new one so started researching lesser known brands.  FIRST MISTAKE .  Even thought TCL makes a lot of parts for Samsung it is not nearly the same.TV arrived very fast from Amazon because they are amazing.  Set up was easy.  Picture settings needed to be adjusted, but that is no big deal. TV worked great after I set up my speakers since the sets sounds is pathetic, but I knew that going in.Fast forward to two months after purchase.  I decided that I was going to mount it on a swivel wall mount.  I followed all instruction and hung the tv and it was great.  2 days later when tilting the tv the screen goes out.  Just like that boom picture gone. I turn it off and on and same thing.  Nothing was showing on the tv including hitting volume, input ect.  I start freaking out, but remember the 2 year limited warranty it came with.  I call TCL customer service (sounds like an India call center btw). After wasting 45 minutes with the employee telling me to unplug then replug,then hit volume then this that and everything, he finally says they will have to send a technician to fix.  Honestly, I am perfectly fine with that considering the time line was 5-7 business days.  One thing that struck me as being odd is they said they would send out a part and then I would need to call back to get a technician.  Wait, how can this person in a different country possibly know what part to send or what is really wrong without seeing the tv.  This makes me believe that they have had issues wit this 40 inch model.  I receive the new part about 2 weeks after initial call.  I call the CS line again and tell thme case number and I have the part so lets send out a damn tech. to get this fixed.  Ok sir, I have now put you in the technician claims que....um what? Yes sir you will be notified in 2-3 days about when the tech. will come out.  Is this a joke?  I am about to waste a whole month with my only TV out of service and this is the best BS they can come out with.I am now furious and demanded a new TV , which they have rejected.  I cannot wait to get this nightmare over with and next time I will spend a few hundred more and get a Samsung directly.Unreal.  Fast forward to 3 weeks now and my TV still does not work.

The final con, is the "Brightness" of this TV when it comes to playing on the Xbox 360, and Using 1080p HD Cables.I haven't tested to see if it would make a difference when hooked up to HDMI, but I kinda doubt it. After around 30 minutes, I got the settings pretty good, but if anyone knows which settings work the best, please comment and let me know.The TV it's self looked new, I'm not even sure if the people before had even turned on the TV as I had to set it up, the only thing that was noticeable, is that the "Changer" came with it's batteries inside, and the wrong screws for the stand.I only wish that the other TV's by TCL had the amazing Contrast ratio that this one does. Reviews.Content: I bought this set because I had a bit of disposable income and was in need of a halfway decent HD TV.MAKE SURE YOU NOTE TO NOT LEAVE THE PACKAGE AT YOUR DOORSTEP. They did that to me, and I'm really lucky I'm in a good neighborhood because it comes in very bright packaging that is clearly a 50" LED TV.The size is wonderful and the viewing angle is just as great. The big issue was that the lighting is a bit inconsistent. Some parts are brighter than others, giving the picture a bit of a weird ripple-like effect. Another problem is the base of the set. I want to avoid moving it much for fear of the neck just snapping off from either the set or the solid glass base.All in all, I would buy this set again. If you're looking for a cheap 50" TV, you'd be hard pressed to find a better one at this price.

Reviews.Content: Bought this TV for our guest bedroom. What a great buy, great picture and sound. Very easy to tune and put together, highly recommend this product.

Reviews.Content: Why pay more? It's just t.v.This t.v. does every single thing a healthy well rounded individual needs.On, off, volume up, volume down, input selection, timer to go off automatically, plus more I'm sure.It's been about 3 months that this t.v. has seen light but enjoyable use. Reviews.Title: Don't be afraid of this TV just because you haven't heard of TCL
Reviews.Author: MARK A GRIFFITH JR
Reviews.Content: I did not want to buy a no name cheapo large screen TV but after doing some research found that TCL is one of the world's largest manufacturer of TVs. So far they seem to be sold mostly in China and other countries so they are little known here and therefore quite a bit less expensive. I bought a 50" for my livingroom and liked it so for Christmas, I got my two adult sons 40 inch versions. They are great, multiple HDMI and other connections, I believe three, easy setup, simple remote and very lightweight. The weight really surprised me as compared to my Panasonic HDTV of 5 years ago. You don't need a crazy sturdy wall mount if you chose to mount them. I did buy a wall mount for the 50" but it looks pretty good on the stand so I've left it on the stand for now. The sound is OK but for such a beautiful picture you should run it through a stereo system, a surround sound system, or a soundbar to get the full effect. Aside from Bose, I can't imagine any TV that has decent bass from the TV speakers, there is just no room for a woofer.

Reviews.Title: Good TV but you have to calibrate it
Reviews.Author: Anna S.
Reviews.Content: This is overall a good TV with good value considering its cost.  The documentation (manual) is not very detailed. I like how thin and light this TV is, which helps when installing it on the wall by yourself. If you are installing this as a table top configuration, be aware that the connection of the baseplate to the TV has slightly different hole spacing for the bolts in the front and the back to ensure that the glass baseplate is placed correctly. The default picture settings are not good, so you have to define your own configuration (personal). I noticed that those settings are unique for each type of input, so for instance if you want the same settings for HDMI1 input and HDMI2 input, you have to define your personal settings twice. After using the THX calibrator and trying five different suggested values proposed by other users, I found that for me, the best picture settings are as follows.Brightness 53Contrast 45Saturation 40Sharpness 15Tint 55Color Mode NormalIf manual backlight is chosen, use 45, otherwise stay with Dynamic Backlight and Dynamic Light Sensor OnFor advanced settings I useZoom Mode No overscan3DNR High (can only be adjusted in TV mode)Film mode on

Reviews.Title: Okay TV
Reviews.Author: Tony
Reviews.Content: This is no Samsung. And not 120Hz, as advertised. Someone should really do something about the claims that are made on these televisions and start a class action lawsuit. It seems almost all the manufacturers are making up facts about their televisions to suit their marketing strategy, rather than actually implementing solid technology to deliver a benefit to consumers. If you're looking for a true 120Hz screen, look elsewhere. Search for 'fake refresh rates is your tv really 120 hz' and you will see what I'm talking about.The screen is good enough, with wide-ranging, customization for color settings which are adequate. I game frequently, and it is suitable for PS3, PS4s, PC, 360, One and Wii -- I've hooked them all up separately to this TV, and played, and not encountered any frame rate issues. It would be nice if there were more HDMI ports. There isn't really any glare or any viewing angle problems, and the picture is crisp enough. If you're willing to accept that you're getting a 60Hz, 50-inch TV for around $400 or $500 bucks shipped to your door, then go ahead and purchase it. I've been using it 4 - 8 hours a day for a month, and have had no problems with the hardware.

Reviews.Title: 50" TCL 1080p 120Hz -- IS ONLY 60Hz, an amazing 60Hz for the price though.
Reviews.Author: Anthony J Francher
Reviews.Content: I had to give this Television 3 stars due to the MARKETING FRAUD. Yes, fraud... This television is Marketed, packaged, labeled, and specified as a 120Hz refresh 1080p 50" Screen.This Screen is 50", provides CRISP & BEAUTIFUL 1080i and 1080p images depending on the device you are connecting it to via HDMI Cables. This truly is an enormous TV, sleek and beautiful. The IMAGE is the best 1080p I have ever seen in ***60Hz*** Refresh Rate. That's right this TV can only refresh up to 60Hz, which is the standard rate of the television world...Save time and $ if you NEED 120Hz and move on. I called TCL USA and they informed me that this TV can only refresh at 60Hz, and don;t "understand" why I think it's supposed to be 120Hz, even the site says in the Specs 120Hz!So... now I have a tough choice to make, return and wait (without tv) and spend more on a different brand that supports true 120Hz, or to KEEP IT since it has the best darn display at the lowest price I have ever seen of a 60Hz!..The only TCL LED TV at 120Hz, is the 58" model the TCL USA CSA told me.  One other issue is much of what is broadcasted on Dish is 1080i, and the TV shows high amounts of grain and sharpness-distortion.  When on ROKU at 1080p, the grain is lost and a very nice clear image is shown, still only in 60Hz though.MY SETTINGS FOR BEST POSSIBLE PICTURE:Brightness: 45Contrast: 58Saturation: 55Sharpness: 50Color Mode: NormalDynamic Backlight: OnDynamic Light Sensor: OffAdvanced:-Zoom Mode: Normal-Film Mode: On*** One other issue I had with this TV is the Digital Output is in ANCIENT RCA Cable style.  In order to connect the Audio out from this TV to most new Surround Sound, you will need 1-Digital RCA Cable 1- Converter RCA-to-Optical and 1-Optical Digital Cable.  It took some time to figure this out, and those parts can be ordered here on Amazon, I got mine on Monoprice.com they provide A+++ Customer Support to help you choose the right components.

The unit has quite good black levels, fully the equal of Sony or Samsung entry level sets, but for way less money. There is some murkiness in dimly lit, low contrast scenes; I guess that's the weakness of LCDs, but I much prefer it to the dull looking, cheaper plasma sets with their visible scan lines. The built-in speakers are not bad (give them 2 weeks playing time and adjust the eq). Of course, the sound is much better with a separate stereo system. Overall, a great bargain.

Better than other TVs, I've tested in the past. The picture quality was also very good, and the sound was good, for the limited testing I did.Anyone purchasing this TV should understand it is not "feature rich". No internet apps, and limited setup controls. For my needs, or anyone that already has external devices that provide those functionalities, it is a very good buy.

Not a bad pic and since everything is broadcast at 60hz anyways I don't know that the 120hz makes much difference. You definitely have to play with the color set up though to dial it in. Reviews.Title: Avoid at all costs, 2 year warranty means nothing!-Updated
Reviews.Author: Becky Swanson
Reviews.Content: Bought this TV brand new from Menard's (with the manufacturer's 2-year warranty), and after only a few months of use the TV started to reverse a section of the image, and become blurry. Called customer support and were told that we were not able to get the TV fixed because we needed a receipt. No problem we thought, and we went back to Menard's to print out the receipt. With that in hand we called customer support again, and were originally told that they were shipping a box so we could exchange the TV for a new one. Good news, we thought! Wrong. They called soon after and said that since it was not the ORIGINAL receipt we could not exchange it. Customer service is absolutely horrible, as is their product, and the two-year warranty means absolutely nothing. Extremely frustrating and pathetic, AVOID TCL AT ALL COSTS!!!UPDATE: I was contacted by a representative of TCL regarding our situation. The representative was helpful and courteous, and the issue was resolved in the form of getting a replacement TV (refurbished, upgraded model). I have changed my rating from 1/5 to a 4/5 due to the excellent customer support received. I left it at a 4 instead of a 5 because the TV did have the issue to begin with, and the customer service was horrible until recently.

Reviews.Title: No surprises here (and at the price that's not a good thing)
Reviews.Author: David Billen
Reviews.Content: The TCL is cheap in price and you probably already have appropriate expectations. Be clear though - if you have any secret hopes that this set will turn out to be a "find" and surprise you with a better picture than the price suggests - that won't happen. It's not a rip off. It's just a crummy little television for people who don't wish to spend much money.PROS:- It works and it's bright.CONS:- The viewing angle is poorer than I expected since I had found a review claiming it was good.- The color can't be set correctly from the user controls, (and an ISF calibration - if it's even possible - would cost more than the set). That's true of a lot of TV's, but since the digital era I've often been surprised with the color accuracy of low end sets. No surprises here.- It has a perfectly adequate user interface (menus, etc), but it's hard to use because the remote buttons are poorly debounced. You sometimes get unexpected results from it, like accidentally pressing twice on a selection. It can be frustrating.- The internal firmware is kind of "amateur" for lack of a better way to characterize it. One arbitrary example, (I could give many others): it has a setting that will cause the backlight to brighten and dim based on the current image. But it is implemented poorly and there is so much obvious brightening and dimming of the output that it's too distracting to use. Like many TCL features, it's in there, but it does not seem to have been implemented by an engineer who was the shiniest coin in the fountain.Summary:If you're oblivious to picture color accuracy (not being cute - many or most people are), and don't plan to watch at much of an angle, then this will give you the biggest brightest picture you can get for the money.

Reviews.Title: Excellent for the price but not without compromise.
Reviews.Author: Anthony
Reviews.Content: As a preface I use this TV as my primary monitor for my gaming PC.The TV is absolutely phenomenal considering how much more you'd have to pay for a comparable Sony or Samsung,the contrast ratio is excellent and the response times are low enough that I don't experience any issues while playing first person shooters.That being said the color reproduction is off out of the box, my particular unit was a tad too blue, luckily this is easily compensated for by adjusting the tint and warm/cool settings but be prepared to tinker for the best image quality.Last but not least my particular unit shows signs of ghosting in bright scenes where there are contrasting blacks or dark colors, it's only noticeable if you get close and personal and is all but impossible to notice at a standard viewing distance of 2+ meters, but it's definitely there even if it is a minor flaw.All in all I would recommend this TV (and have) because of the amazing price to performance point that it fills.Also, did I mention that this thing weighs only slightly more than a feather?All in all 4/5.

Reviews.Content: I purchased this tv after reading the reviews, most of which where very good, it came in quickly, was in perfect condition and was set up quickly. Here is the only issue that I had. I checked the code for Comcast so that I could program my cable remote and the code didn't work. After trying a few different codes, I called Comcast and the guy said there were only 2 codes and neither of them worked, he said I would have to return the remote which I wasn't gonna do because I'm stubborn, I researched and someone said to use the codes for RCA and that is exactly what I did and the first RCA code I plugged in worked like a charm!!! I believe it was 0778 but not completely sure on that. Anyway, I adjusted the color a bit since I found it to be a bit to sharp for my liking and now its perfect!! The price on this was only $329. for a 40" and it makes a big difference watching it versus a 32". The sound quality is great and if you have a surround sound you can connect it. This is what I call a bargain!!! Thanks Amazon and TCL for making my hubby a very happy man!!!

For example, at night I like turn the backlight and color brightness all the way down. It's a pain to have to change it back and forth manually rather than just switching between profiles. Perhaps a firmware update could provide this?

Its not too bad tho and if I didn't have another 32" sitting in storage from a freebie w/furniture I would buy another for basement if needed.

Reviews.Content: I spent 300 and some change to the door with tax and next day shipping.  I challenge you to find another TV in this class and size for that kind of price!  Very happy with the picture and performance....I highly recommend!

Reviews.Title: Great Value
Reviews.Author: Gail D. Huhges
Reviews.Content: I used a cordless drill to quickly install the long base screws. Mistake. I had set the chuck to slip at "gentle" resistance, but there is no setting on a power drill soft enough for this installation. The plastic on the base where it mates to the television is not strong. The base under the screw head looked slightly contorted and I didn't turn the screw again because I was pretty sure the screw threads reamed the plastic hole. I hand tightened the other three with good success. The 40" TV has a somewhat small base. Now because of the TV to base size contrast and 3 out of 4 screw tightness, the TV has a comical bobble whenever it is touched or the furniture is bumped. Comical and stomach turning. I suspect it would bobble like that even if I hand tightened all four screws. It only has two HDMI inputs, but this suits me (for now). I had no issues with out of the box color and picture settings. I tried the two detailed in the reviews and did NOT like the results. I easily had it reset to default and it suits our partially-lit room. For the price...what a deal!

Reviews.Content: This TV works great! It was the best deal I could find and doesn't come with the smart-TV gimmicky stuff. (You can easily use an HDMI cable and hook it up to your computer!)

Reviews.Title: TCL Warranty Support Experience
Reviews.Author: Chad Jacob "tech enthusiast"
Reviews.Content: This review is of the TCL warranty support service and not the quality of the TV picture itself. As this experience progresses I will update this review.The TV failed in just under 4 months with the screen shutting off while in use followed by a loud "pop" or "bang" from the unit 5 seconds later and a slight burnt odor.Going to TCl's "contact us" page you find a simple and inviting form as well as a toll free number. The TV failed on December 24th so I wasn't expecting anyone would answer but I did expect the recording to say when they will be back from the holidays. Instead the recording simply informed "Our offices are closed, please call back Monday-Friday between 9am-9pm EST".So no indication when they are open again... alright. I called back again during their stated hours on December 26th to be greeted by the same message once again. Alright then... I go back to their website's contact form, fill in all the information, serial number etc. and a very detailed description of the issue, submit it... then the page finally loads and gives me this message:"An error occurred in the application and your page could not be served. Please try again in a few moments.If you are the application owner, check your logs for details."Great. So I close the webpage, go back in, fill it all in again, submit it... all the page says now: "ERROR:500"So at this point there is no way to find out when their support line will be staffed again, and a form cannot be submitted online. Every other portion of their website works, but the moment I submit the warranty support form... errors abound after 3 separate attempts.UPDATE:After the holidays their phone support line was staffed again and I was able to get through, I gave them all of my information on the TV sent via email as instructed and was told I would receive an email back right away with my case number... 4 days later, no case number. So I called again after letting that time pass and got the same guy I talked to the first time, he gave me the case number over the phone saying he had received the email and told me he would forward the information to the returns department.A couple days later the return department called asking for my address and asked if I had the original packaging which I did. She said someone else would send an email with a postage paid UPS return label which I received a day later. So I sent the TV off the first week of January. A week later I sent an email to the same address asking how long I should expect to wait for my TV to be repaired... never got a reply.So in summary it took 33 days from the time the TV failed till it was fixed and back in my possession. I did not have to pay anything during the whole process.Hopefully my experience is helpful in some way :)

Reviews.Title: Shipped late.  Missing base.  Appears to be a used TV repackaged and sold as new.
Reviews.Author: JLH
Reviews.Content: We received this TV a day later than expected, even though it was supposed to be delivered via Prime service.  When it arrived, we were surprised to discover that it was missing the base.  The interior styrofoam packaging had been broken in half, and we saw that all of the plastic covers that are normally protecting the screens and covering new equipment had been removed as well (with only a remnant remaining in one corner).  It was pretty obvious that this was a used TV that had been stuffed back in the box and passed off as new.  Without a base, it was inoperable.We contacted TCL to ask if they would deliver a new base, and they said they could but had no idea how long it would take or even if they could.  It would take 24-48 hours for them just to receive and review our invoice from Amazon before they could take any other steps.  The customer service representative was clearly from another country and couldn't have cared less that we were missing anything or that the TV appeared to be used, not new.  They did not seem to take any responsibility for their product.Thank goodness we ordered this from Amazon and are able to return it to them.  Makes you wonder what else they are selling as new that has been repackaged.

Reviews.Title: POOR COLOR QUALITY
Reviews.Author: MKAudioVisualWeb
Reviews.Content: At first glance, this TV seemed perfect for what my wife and I needed as a secondary TV. Ultimately, the TCL 40 inch LED TV with 60hz refresh rate performed sub-par in two important categories:1.) COLOR QUALITY - The most noticeable flaw. I am an audio-visual guy, that's what my bachelor's degree is in, yet I really am not extremely picky when it comes to 'perfect' color/white balancing. But, this TV's colors were so poor it was to the point of being unacceptable. I'm not sure if the other reviewers are color blind, or are just buying a TV for one of their kids who just won't notice/care, but even after making many adjustments to the poorly configured picture settings panel such as the saturation, contrast, and tint, I could only fix the problem so much.- Skin tone was the most noticeable failure. Peoples' faces were ORANGE. Not even close to passable.- Whites ended up being either way to blue/cold or way to warm/yellow.- Blacks were actually decent, but I did some reading and apparently the company has to do some serious color processing after the fact to make up for what it lacks in good components.2.) AUDIO QUALITY - Weak, but passable. No one can expect amazing sound quality from the built in speakers of a flat-screen TV. I do have to say the mids where a little to intense for my liking, obviously there is little to no bass response.Overall, I gave this TV a 2 star rating because, although it didn't even come close to living up to my expectations, this TV would be PERFECT for gamers, cartoons, or animated movies. I do have to say that the brightness of this TV will beat any LCD TV, so if brightness and crispness is your top priority within a budget, this may be your TV.After being this disappointed with the orange tinge of every person's face in every single movie/show I watched, I returned it and ended up getting the 39 inch Vizio  Smart TV 120hz refresh rate. I had never gotten a Visio before this one, but decided to get it after hearing that it is the top name in LED technology right now, so I gave it a shot, and I'm very pleased with it so far.If you are at all like me and care about whether or not people have orange faces on your new TV, I would have to suggest spending the 50-70 dollars more and get a better quality TV.

Reviews.Title: Only 60Hz refresh rate
Reviews.Author: Todd B
Reviews.Content: The TLC website, the amazon listing and even the box it came in listed it as having a 120Hz refresh rate, however, the manual only states it's 60Hz and after setting it up and connecting various devices to it, the only refresh rate I ever got was 60Mz. I contacted TLC customer service and was told that it was "capable" of 120Hz but the fact that it was only at 60Hz was due to my devices and/or cable box settings (this is patently false). I pointed out that my other TVs which have 120Hz and 240Hz refresh rates were plugged in to the exact same devices yet they displayed their advertised refresh rates and didn't go down to 60Hz because of some phantom settings on any devices. The customer service rep. then began to read the same response back to me ad nauseum, "it's capable of 120Hz". If that's not enough, the picture is often fuzzy/blurry during sports (due to low refresh rate) and the colors make everyone look like garish clowns but when you try to tone it down, it often makes it worse. It was a great price, but not a great product, and I'm especially astonished at TLC's flagrant false advertising on their description of the TV
